desc: RRAS encodes R-Ras, a member of the Rassubfamily of small GTPases, which is involved in diverse processes includingangiogenesis, vascular homeostasis, vascular regeneration, cell adhesion andneuronal axon guidance. R-Ras signaling regulates the organization of the actincytoskeleton and promotes the formation of ruffling lamellipodia via its activationof phospholipase Cε (PMID: 16537651). R-Ras regulates Integrin β1 activity andaffects cell adhesion, cell spreading, cell polarization and phagocytosis (PMID: 8620538,18270267, 11257001). In addition, R-Ras inhibits angiogenesis and endothelialcell vessel sprouting but promotes vascular homeostasis due to its effect onVascular endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) signaling (PMID: 27029009). Germlinemutations in this gene are found in disorders related to Noonan Syndrome collectively called "RASopathies", and somatic alterations have been found to beassociated with hematologic and pediatric cancers (PMID: 24705357).

articles.title: The small GTPase R-Ras regulates organization of actin and drives membrane protrusions through the activity of PLCepsilon.
articles.reference: Ada-Nguema AS et al. Journal of cell science. 2006 Apr 1;119(Pt 7)1307-19.

articles.title: The R-Ras interaction partner ORP3 regulates cell adhesion.
articles.reference: Lehto M et al. Journal of cell science. 2008 Mar 1;121(Pt 5)695-705.

articles.title: Analysis of R-Ras signalling pathways.
articles.reference: Self AJ et al. Journal of cell science. 2001 Apr;114(Pt 7)1357-66.

articles.title: Activating mutations in RRAS underlie a phenotype within the RASopathy spectrum and contribute to leukaemogenesis.
articles.reference: Flex E et al. Human molecular genetics. 2014 Aug 15;23(16)4315-27.

articles.title: R-Ras Inhibits VEGF-Induced p38MAPK Activation and HSP27 Phosphorylation in Endothelial Cells.
articles.reference: Sawada J et al. Journal of vascular research. 2015;52(5)347-59.

articles.title: Integrin activation by R-ras.
articles.reference: Zhang Z et al. Cell. 1996 Apr 5;85(1)61-9.

desc: RRAS is a small GTPase, and mutations in this gene are found in disorders termed "RASopathies" as well as in hematologic and pediatric cancers.
